item.title: Occupational Safety and Health Small Business Day in Court Act of 2005

latestAction.text: Received in the Senate and Read twice and referred to the Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions.

item.title: Occupational Safety and Health Review Commission Efficiency Act of 2005

latestAction.text: Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 351, H.R. 740 is laid on the table.

item.title: Occupational Safety and Health Independent Review of OSHA Citations Act of 2005

latestAction.text: Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 351, H.R. 741 is laid on the table.

item.title: Occupational Safety and Health Small Employer Access to Justice Act of 2005

latestAction.text: Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 351, H.R. 742 is laid on the table.

item.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by recorded vote: 224 - 189 (Roll no. 366). (text: CR H5661)
Passed/agreed to in House: On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by recorded vote: 224 - 189 (Roll no. 366).(text: CR H5661)
On ordering the previous question Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 223 - 191 (Roll no. 365). (consideration: CR H5674-5675; text: CR H5674)
DEBATE - The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Res. 351.
Considered as privileged matter. (consideration: CR H5661-5676)
Placed on the House Calendar, Calendar No. 60.

The rule provides for separate consideration in the House of H.R. 739, H.R. 740, H.R. 741 and H.R. 742. The rule provides one hour of general debate for each bill, equally divided and controlled. The amendments in the nature of a substitute recommended by the Committee on Education and the Workforce now printed in H.R. 740 and H.R. 741, shall be considered as adopted. In the engrossment of H.R. 739, the Clerk shall add the texts of H.R. 740, H.R. 741, and H.R. 742, as passed by the House, as new matter at the end of H.R. 739, and then lay on the table H.R. 740, H.R. 741, and H.R. 742. If H.R. 739 is disposed of without reaching the stage of engrossment, then whichever of the 3 remaining bills first passes the House shall be treated in the manner specified for H.R. 739 and all other bills which have passed the House shall be laid on the table.
The House Committee on Rules reported an original measure, H. Rept. 109-163, by Mr. Bishop (UT).
The House Committee on Rules reported an original measure, H. Rept. 109-163, by Mr. Bishop (UT).

summary.text:
Sets forth the rule for consideration of: (1) H.R. 739 (Occupational Safety and Health Small Business Day in Court Act of 2005); (2) H.R. 740 (Occupational Safety and Health Review Commission Efficiency Act of 2005); (3) H.R. 741 (Occupational Safety and Health Independent Review of OSHA Citations Act of 2005); and (4) H.R. 742 (Occupational Safety and Health Small Employer Access to Justice Act of 2005).

Requires the Clerk of the House of Representatives, in the engrossment of H.R. 739, to: (1) await the disposition of H.R. 740, H.R. 741, and H.R. 742; (2) add their respective texts, as passed by the House, as new matter at the end of H.R. 739; (3) conform the title of H.R. 739 to reflect such addition; (4) assign appropriate designations to provisions within the engrossment; and (5) conform provisions for short titles within the engrossment.

Provides that: (1) upon the addition of the text of such bills that have passed the House to the engrossment of H.R. 739, they shall be laid on the table; and (2) if H.R. 739 is disposed of without reaching the engrossment stage, the bill in this Act that first passes the House shall be treated in the same specified manner as H.R. 739 and all other bills in this Act that have passed the House shall be laid on the table.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced. The summary of that version is repeated here.)

bill.title: Providing for the consideration of the bill (H.R. 739) to amend the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 to provide for adjudicative flexibility with regard to the filing of a notice of contest by an employer following the issuance of a citation or proposed assessment of a penalty by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration; for consideration of the bill (H.R. 740) to amend the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 to provide for greater efficiency at the Occupational Safety and Health Review Commission; for consideration of the bill (H.R. 741) to amend the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 to provide for judicial deference to conclusions of law determined by the Occupational Safety and Health Review Commission with respect to an order issued by the Commission; and for consideration of the bill (H.R. 742) to amend the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 to provide for the award of attorneys' fees and costs to small.

item.title: Providing for the consideration of the bill (H.R. 739) to amend the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 to provide for adjudicative flexibility with regard to the filing of a notice of contest by an employer following the issuance of a citation or proposed assessment of a penalty by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration; for consideration of the bill (H.R. 740) to amend the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 to provide for greater efficiency at the Occupational Safety and Health Review Commission; for consideration of the bill (H.R. 741) to amend the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 to provide for judicial deference to conclusions of law determined by the Occupational Safety and Health Review Commission with respect to an order issued by the Commission; and for consideration of the bill (H.R. 742) to amend the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 to provide for the award of attorneys' fees and costs to small.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
